keyTakeAways: The death toll from flooding in central and southeastern Mexico has risen to at least 44, with Mexico’s El Universal reporting 48 deaths, indicating a severe humanitarian crisis.

Floods triggered by two tropical storms — remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond — have caused landslides and widespread damage across five states: Veracruz, Puebla, Hidalgo, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi.
Fatalities were distributed as 18 in Veracruz, 16 in Hidalgo, 9 in Puebla, and 1 in Queretaro, highlighting regional vulnerability and disproportionate impact.
Around 320,000 people have experienced power outages, and at least 16,000 homes have been damaged, emphasizing the scale of infrastructure and civilian disruption.
The Mexican military has been mobilized to assist in rescue operations and aid distribution, reflecting the government’s emergency response to the disaster.
Photos from the military show evacuation efforts, flooded homes, and rescue workers navigating waist-high waters, illustrating the physical conditions and human suffering.
The current flooding is linked to the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which dumped heavy rainfall on western Mexico, contributing to extreme weather conditions.
Mexico City has recorded its rainiest June in over two decades, indicating a broader climate trend of increased precipitation and potential worsening of extreme weather events.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Torrential rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond have caused devastating floods and landslides across central and southeastern Mexico, including Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, Queretaro, and San Luis Potosi. The death toll has climbed to at least 44, with some sources citing 48, and dozens still missing. The disaster has led to widespread power outages, with over 320,000 people affected and 16,000 homes damaged. The Mexican government has activated the military to conduct evacuations and deliver emergency aid, as flooding continues to threaten additional communities. The event is linked to broader climate trends, including Mexico City’s record-breaking rainfall in June, suggesting increasing vulnerability to extreme weather events.
title: Death toll from Mexico flooding rises to 44, dozens more missing
